title: If everyone is allowed to own lands permanently, then what happens when there are too many people and not enough lands (or houses)? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: There is a singular critical issue. The climate/climate change. You can put people in arid areas, subject to floods, too hot, no water, freezing cold and more that make living in these areas uninhabitable. Or if forced to live on the land, they will die. Few would be able to build anything due to the climate and lack of building material Current climate changes are making more areas uninhabitable thereby forcing humans into areas that are now facing many more changes over the next few years than that over several previous decades- maybe a century or more. We are already at the point of too many people on the land that can be reasonably occupied. This will cause pandemics (I said that 20 years ago- thought it might be the bird flu in 2005) and another one by 2035 (I am thinking by 2030). Add in much greater damage by hurricanes, tornados, heat, and the human race may be on the way out.

Well I guess Luke that people would just not be able to buy any land until some became available, same for housing. However, we only have decades, perhaps 20 to 50 years or less before society collapses through anthropogenic global warming & climate change, then none of this will matter anymore.
